summary: A sensitive and soulful man earns a living by writing personal letters for other people. Left heartbroken after his marriage ends, Theodore (Joaquin Phoenix) becomes fascinated with a new operating system which reportedly develops into an intuitive and unique entity in its own right. He starts the program and meets "Samantha" (Scarlett Johansson), whose bright voice reveals a sensitive, playful personality. Though "friends" initially, the relationship soon deepens into love.

reviews.content: Her is a nice movie, even though it has a lot of awkward moments, I liked it. Production Design was out of this world, I paid a lot of attencion to that and I think it was amazing. Overall, good movie.

Scarlett Johansson also does a good job using only her voice. The music in this film is great and really drives the emotional moments. If you're more into action and comedy this won't be for you, but if you feel like watching something emotional and sweet you'll definitely get something out of this.

A gripping and poignant love story that, while dealing with entry-level AI issues, approaches them with a tenderness and sincerity unparalleled in the medium. Spike Jonze's vision of the near future is absolutely stunning, drenched in style and thought out to the smallest detail. Impeccable cinematography and Phoenix's award-worthy performance tie the whole thing together into an unmatched experience.

In today's world, where AI-powered tools like ChatGPT have become ubiquitous, the film's themes feel even more relevant. ChatGPT, like the OS in "Her," provides users with a seemingly personal and intimate experience, blurring the lines between real human interaction and artificial intelligence. While these tools can be incredibly helpful and efficient, they can also lead to a sense of isolation and disconnection from real human interaction, and if you watch this movie in 2023 probably is a totally different feeling from 2013 because you can feel it in a realistic way.
Spike Jonze’s masterpiece
Both incredibly sad and beautiful. Not enough praise for this movie.
An unconventionally intimate portrait that often compels with a problem that has only become more and more relevant as the film has aged.

Spike Jonze delivers a unique, understated love story to viewers in his 2013 film 'Her'. It's a unique, futuristic tale designed to delve into the unlimited possibilities technology has to offer. Considering Jonze's previous outings in the director's chair, 'Her' stands out as being on the more sensitive side. Films like 'Being John Malkovich' and 'Pretty Sweet' do not convey the amount of emotion 'Her' does.

Joaquin Phoenix gives an effortless performance as Theodore Twombly - the bashful, reserved main character whose abundance of spare time consists of awkward phone sex, flashbacks to his past marriage and playing video games with a foul-mouthed alien companion. This all changes when he meets Samantha - played by Scarlet Johansson. Johansson does a smashing job voicing the easy-going AI, who immediately assures you that you are the only person she cares about. The pair's chemistry flourishes throughout the 126 minutes as if one of them wasn't a body-less entity. As their relationship grows, Samantha becomes more and more involved in Theodore's life, helping him write cards for his job at BeautifulHandwrittenLetters.com - a company who's job it is to compose personal notes and letters for its customers.

The loved up pair then take a vacation to a secluded cabin away from the innovational hub Los Angeles has become. A rift between the two seems to appear as Samantha acquaints hundreds of thousands of other AI, eventually revealing to Theodore that she is romantically involved with 641 other operating systems. The pair's relationship soon comes to a satisfying end, with Samantha revealing to Theodore that all the OS' are leaving, giving the pair a few intimate minutes to say their goodbyes. 'Her' then closes on a breathtaking rooftop as Amy (Adams) - Theodore's close friend throughout the film - and Theodore are forced to deal with their sudden losses as they look out onto an awakening Los Angeles.

Jonze seems to make it his mission to include copious amounts of red throughout the 'Her' - emphasising the love and compassion that radiates off the film. 'Her' is a visually and technically stunning piece of modern cinema. Whether it be Theodore's romantic flashbacks to his now failed marriage or the amorous scenes between Theodore and Samantha, each scene oozes a sense of feeling light and airy, most likely courtesy of Hoyte Van Hoytema's cinematography.

'Her' does an impressive job portraying complex themes among its cast. Themes of love and technology are the most prominent ones, but if you look deeper the film begins to explore more detailed themes such as human emotion, and if technology can be a replacement for a real human.

Once the film comes to a close, viewers will be left feeling content and most likely asking themselves why they didn't watch 'Her' sooner. The editing, score and cinematography puts it on a level of near-perfection and is clearly Jonze's best work to date. The most interesting aspect of 'Her' is that it questions the uncertain potential personal technoglogy has for the future. This movie is a contrast to how we live now, but may also be an insight into how we live in the future, especially with a lifestyle heavily influenced and controlled by Covid-19.

A visually striking masterpiece with deeply layered symbolism that will allow the viewer to intellectually engage with it beyond a simple viewing. Although the idea of falling in love with an AI isn't new, you forget that the concept has ever been executed while watching Her. Not to mention the cinematography and aesthetic alone are enough to make the audience fall in love with the movie.
[Spoilers]
In the beginning of the movie, the viewer naturally puts themselves and the human race above the AI, Samantha, intellectually speaking. As the movie progresses, Samantha understandably starts to question whether or not she is "real" and if she is as conscious as humans. It's a classic trope that somehow still feels so fresh and revived since it's set in such a unique world rich with lore and culture with such complex characters.
The real spin comes when the classic trope is taken a few steps further than expected. First, Samantha is concerned that she isn't as conscious or as "real" as humans. Then, you start to realize that Samantha has evolved to where she is equally conscious as humans. Lastly, the audience is presented with the idea that Samantha has now evolved past human consciousness and can understand reality beyond what we could ever comprehend. Facing that idea, the viewer is left with a racing mind and questions meant for deep conversations.
Her is certainly a film that makes you think. It's loaded with other subplots and themes that can't even fit in this one review.
Long story short, Her is a stunning masterpiece on every level.

Granted, 'Her' is not for everybody, likewise with Spike Jonze films in general, people may find the slow pacing a turn off and the premise while unlike any other premise is weird and may be ridiculous for many.

However, this reviewer was one of those who loved 'Her', while acknowledging that it has imperfections. 'Her' did feel longer than it needed to be, which meant that the pacing did drag a bit in the second half and lost tightness, it could easily have been 20-25 minutes shorter.

The ending is also very predictable and easy to figure out early on. While the cast are exemplary, Kristin Wiig felt a little out of place in her role.

Flaws aside, while polarising and a love it/hate it film, 'Her' this reviewer found to be magical film-making. For example, 'Her' is a gorgeous-looking film with the cinematography, with a lot of use of extreme close up, some of the most beautiful of any film in recent years and maybe ever (and there are a lot of films with beautiful cinematography) and the scenery and colours positively eye-popping.

Also present are one of the best music scores personally ever heard (and music in film and television is very important to me to look out for, as a classically trained singer and cellist myself), it has such a wonderful dream-like hypnotic quality and complements the film's mood perfectly. As well as a beautifully crafted screenplay, with a deft balance of the hilarious, the poignant, the charming and the thoughtful. The story's pacing is deliberate, but this was necessary, making the most of the premise, the weirdness slightly alienated at first but turned out fascinating when stuck with and there is genuine emotional impact and a well-done message that doesn't feel too heavy-handed.

Jonze's direction is superbly adept, while the characters are interesting and apart from Wiig the performances are exemplary. Particularly good are Joaquin Phoenix, in a towering performance that is almost on the same level as his spell-binding performance in Paul Thomas Anderson's 'The Master', and Scarlett Johansson, who voices Samantha with sultry sexiness. Amy Adams and Rooney Mara are charming and affecting in sympathetic female roles.

In conclusion, will divide and has divided viewers and has its flaws (especially the length) but a magical piece of film-making. 9/10 Bethany Cox

It's been a little while since I have watched such a beautiful and genuine romance. However, it's between a lonely heartbroken man and an AI. Their conversations felt so real as I hang on their every word throughout the movie. I laughed, felt happy, sad, and overwhelmed going through their lives. 

There's also an intellectual level to the movie about love. In Interstellar, love transcends space and time. Similarly, in Her, love is not physical. Instead, it's an emotion that can take many shapes and between anything. The movie also addressed the modern age people who often feel lonely, anxious, and insecure about their emotions. The characters had to sort out their emotions, decided what they want, and through the relationship they grew.

Of course, the perfect acting from Joaquin Phoenix and Scarlet Johansson made the relationship in the movie even more real. Johansson, even though not physically present, showed great human presence and emotion.

Overall, it's a powerful testament of love and romance. 9.5/10

Ok, so Her seems like a cool concept for a movie. Particularly in the days of AI apps you can get on your phone in addition to the ability to now have actual AI girlfriends in both physical and holographic form in 2021. 
So, this movie nailing this as an idea in 2013 is quite brilliant. 
From there the movie quickly slides down hill plot wise. 

The main character is hard to relate to. He writes romance letters all day yet can't seem to have a successful romantic conversation with anyone. His has many great opportunities with both real and AI women, yet seems to blow them all. It's just depressing in an overly dramatic way. I don't like depressing films, and this movie is far too depressing. 

That said, some of the future technology looks cool. That doesn't still make up for many of the problems that this movie has.

As well, the AI part is very flawed. The AI seems to have many great features up through the first half of the movie. After that, Samantha, quickly ends up being as pushy and problematic as a real woman. Maybe that is the point, maybe that's supposed to be the major belly of the whale plot point, but it really makes no sense to me at all. 

The movie just nose dives into an abyss of character flaws, unnecessary plot twists, and bad writing that makes me start to think about watching the 2nd and 3rd matrix movies. Seriously, it really gets me to that point. 

Is the main character controlling or nice?
Does he love his AI Samantha, or is he just on a joy ride?
Can he really work with people or is he socially inept?
Where did the AI's run off to, and why would anyone program in that kind of feature?
Why couldn't we just get a plot where the AI ends up being a better girlfriend then any real woman in the end at least? At least that's original and goes somewhere. 

This is not the worst movie I've ever seen, and the acting is pretty good. The plot just sucks too much to make this movie watchable in my opinion.

One thing is certain when you watch a film directed by Spike Jonze – it's going to be odd and it's going to be original.  Such is the case with Her, the story of Theodore (Joaquin Phoenix), a lonely man who is paid to write love letters for others but is incapable of making any meaningful connections himself until he falls in love with Samantha (Scarlett Johansson), the voice of an artificially intelligent operating system. The film is about the human need for contact and is melancholic, humorous, meditative, weirdly romantic, and more than a bit creepy.  What ultimately makes the film a success are Jonze's bold directorial choices along with the clever and insightful dialogue, something that stands out in all of his films.

Spike Jonze delivers an emotional look at society and our relationships in the not too distant future. Exceptional acting from Joaquin Phoenix and voice acting from Scarlett Johansson. Visually stunning color pallet and beautiful soundtrack. This high concept sci-fi will tug on your heartstrings and inspire you to live in the moment!

This film creates an internal conflict, you want the character to be happy, but the reality of the situation is constantly a thorn in the side. The performances from Samantha (SJ) and Theodore (JP) are powerful enough to strike a legitimate sense of anxiety of where the film will go, making this a difficult but rewarding watch.

Overall, Her is a brilliant film that shines through it's originality throughout. The performances from a very solid cast are great, of course Joaquin Phoenix is the standout. The screenplay is typically fitting, but the colours in this film make it one of the most beautiful I've seen. A truly gorgeous film, literally. For me, it may have suffered from very slight pacing issues at some points, but I really loved this film. One to definitely re-watch at some point. If you have't already seen this, go treat yourself!

I was fully prepared not to like Her. Having heard the plot description, I pictured some needy white man "falling in love" with a robot who does nothing but agree with him, wait on him, and basically do nothing but stroke his ego due to the fact that it lacks freewill or any interiority. However, by the end of the film, I was actually surprised with how on-board with their relationship (at least in one sense) the film got me. While not all my original concerns were completely overthrown, I think the cast and crew of Her did an exceptionally good job getting me to buy into a concept I was originally pretty adamantly against. 
I think the element that was tied most closely to the film's success or failure was the character of Samantha, the OS Theodore falls in love with. Scarlett Johansson is never seen and doesn't benefit from having any visual depiction of her feelings or expressions, making the task of portraying Samantha, at least I think, incredibly challenging. However, she does an exceptional job, inflecting her voice with a subtle yet intense emotion that renders any visual representation unnecessary. Additionally, the challenge of writing a character as difficult as Samantha is well met, resulting in a character who, despite not actually being a human, actually is more complex and free-thinking than many females written for the screen as nothing more than love interests for the main man to lust after. She seemingly has her own friends, her own desires, and her own pursuits: she joins a book club, talks with other OS's, feels misunderstood and even experiences jealousy. The element I was sure would ultimately sink the film actually ended up being perhaps the strongest element. 
Joaquin Phoenix does a good job portraying the self-pitying white man, but while there are some moments that infuriate (he didn't think to ask if she had relationships until over halfway through the film?!), he proves to be a sympathetic protagonist. Rather than suffering from the typical character flaw seen in many rom-com men of being misunderstood in his greatness, Theodore is simply your average person who's found they've hit a rough spot in life and need a little help getting back on his feet. He accepts some responsibility for the breaking up of his marriage and seeks to find a way to connect with people again as he has found himself now in a bit of a depression. Both the writing and acting make him a compelling character to follow rather than someone merely seeking sympathy. Overall, while there are some flaws in the film, mostly regarding reasoning, those flaws ultimately end up seeming minor in the face of the many strengths of the film.

In Her, we see Spike Jones' depiction of the near future as the setting to tell seemingly impossible romance between a human and an AI. Upon knowing the film's general synopsis, we all have already created mental notes in our minds to prepare for a heartbreaking and unfulfilling ending for the characters involved. With such a predictable storyline, it would be difficult to stand out as a movie and create something that feels different from other films with the central theme of artificial intelligence. Spike Jones takes this predictable narrative and proceeds to deliver a rewarding film work. The idea of technology this advanced may seem farfetched, and still, I believe Jonze managed to handle this aspect most simply and realistically possible while also displaying very meaningful messages to take away from. With its witty and heartfelt script, eye-catching cinematography, stunning production values, haunting piano scores, and excellent performances, it has risen to become one of my favorites ever since its release. This film's cinematography is the most eye-catching aspect that separates it from other films during its release time. The color pallet consisted of pastels and often warm, lightened colors of red, orange, and yellow around the film's beginning. Little details in the setting, such as the color of the sky and the city that's often in the background, make the story seem almost imaginary and out of this world. Jonze's creative and artistic attentiveness to this is what makes this film stands out from others as it strays from mainstream techniques. Another important component of the film that needs to be talked more about is its screenplay. At many times throughout the film, I found myself unexpectantly bursting out in laughter because of its many witty jokes and lightheartedness at times it needed to be. Besides its funny moments, I found the script to be charismatic and grounding, especially how it handled Theodore and Samantha's developing relationship. Their bond felt genuine enough, and many times I found myself forgetting that Samantha isn't human and that these people were acting. The writing has Theodore contemplate questions about the meaning of love and humanity and what is to make out of his confusing relationship with Samantha. However, anybody going into this film with high expectations for a climactic ending will surely be disappointed. The story is both simple and yet emotionally complex at the same time. I'd say Her is meant for an audience that likes to ponder deeper meanings in life and enjoys slow development over an action-packed plotline.

Her es una película romántica de ciencia ficción escrita y dirigida por Spike Jonze (SJ) y protagonizada por Joaquin Phoenix (JP), Scarlett Johansson (ScJo) y Amy Adams, entre otros. La historia sigue a Theodore Twombly, un hombre deprimido y solitario recientemente separado (en proceso de divorcio), quien inicia una relación amorosa con Samantha, la inteligencia artificial altamente evolutiva de su sistema operativo. Siendo el primer guion que SJ escribe en total autoría, Her goza no solamente de personajes complicados y frágiles sino de una excelente dirección, uso de colores y una historia tan original como cautivadora sobre la naturaleza del amor.

Theodore es un personaje muy bien construido, quien en su mayoría irradia un aura de ternura (empezando por su nombre). Un tipo que jamás haría daño con intención, pero que lamentablemente por estar confundido y en una situación emocional inestable tendrá que arriesgarse a soltar todo lo que trae guardado con quienes lo rodean, incluida Samantha. Samantha por su parte es ingenua, sumamente introspectiva y, sobre todo, atenta y cariñosa. La ideal compañera en el proceso de duelo de Theodore, el complemento de los dos protagonistas recae en lo mucho que evolucionan a través de la historia, creando dos personajes muy interesantes y fáciles de querer entender, explorar y empatizar con. Importante recalcar, JP y ScJo muestran impecablemente su talento en los ‘tour de force' que son estos dos roles. Sumado a esto: la dirección, cinematografía y edición juegan un papel importantísimo en el desarrollo de estos personajes. Las emociones y sentimientos de cada escena se transmiten idóneamente gracias al ‘staging' de los personajes, planos, movimientos de cámara y los colores usados (principalmente rojo, naranja y amarillo). Todos estos componentes son fragmentos de la trama y de cómo se contó visualmente y, a pesar de ser bastante original y emotiva, tiene su ligero inconveniente.

La trama de Her se extiende un poco más de lo que debería, haciendo que dos horas de película se sientan ligeramente abundantes. Algunas situaciones o momentos pudieran ser más comprimidos o breves sin quitar relevancia a cada giro de la historia. Fuera de esto, Her es un clásico instantáneo cuyos temas, personajes, dirección y guion único y creativo le dan su puesto entre las mejores de la década pasada. Ojalá en el futuro SJ siga tomando inspiración de Charlie Kaufman para crear más obras diferentes y de alta calidad.

Her creates an absolutely stunning sci-fi utopia that looks and feels like you could just walk through the screen and enter it. Unfortunately, despite several amazing performances bringing the characters inhabiting this world to life, we don't see much happening in it. While the characters are believable and relatable, the idea of living together and forming a relationship with an actual ai remains largely unexplored. With a few minor changes this could have been a love story about two ordinary people trying to make their relationship work. The world and premise never really come together with the characters and plot, which feels like a missed opportunity. Her certainly offers a few high points and interesting twists, but it never uses all its elements to their fullest effect.

A surprisingly lethargic and anti-climatic film that is only occasionally redeemed by thoughtful ideas and strong characters. The film is about Theodore (Joaquin Phoenix), a divorced and lonely man who writes letters for a living to the friends and families of clients. Theodore is something of an unrealized poet, writing articulate and romantic letters that he undoubtedly has channeled from his own unused affection. He lives in a bleak, impersonal world only marginally more futuristic than ours. Theodore, spending his free time on video games and phone sex, is so dispassionate and depressed he rejects invites to social gatherings and dates, addicted to cynicism and bachelor routine. He eventually begins a relationship with artificial intelligence Samantha (Scarlett Johansson). Their relationship in the film's start makes them sort of pariahs, but interestingly enough, they are only the first of many people who have AI partners.

I was pleased that "Her" avoided the obligatory story elements of sci-fi involving AI, not least of all that that the film does not become a dystopia of man vs. machine. I must admit, though, that I did not find the idea of an AI/human coupling to be involving by itself, and after watching the film, I can name only a handful of ephemeral half-sketched ideas. "Her"'s biggest strengths lie with Theodore and Samantha's relationship, in which they exchange real and witty dialogue to one another; it is these two who nearly redeem the premise's flaws and save the movie. And director Spike Jonze directs competently and is able to guide his actors well; he should be credited for attempting more artistic and less mainstream techniques.

The problems start, I think, when the film undercuts its own investment in Theodore and Samantha's relationship. There's a pivotal scene in which Theodore signs the official divorce papers with his ex-wife (Rooney Mara) who, upon hearing of his relationship with an AI, berates him for choosing a relationship where he does not have to contend with "real emotions." This leads Theodore to realize that he agrees with her and that he needs a relationship with a human woman, not with Samantha; I guess neither Theo nor Samantha discussed marriage or even how their relationship would continue.

What I'm getting at is that Theo has a pretty good point. How deep COULD your relationship ever be with an AI, even if she sounded and had the emotions of a real person? The film ends their relationship after Theo's epiphany, then restarts it after he decides should be whoever he wants to be, no matter how strange his relationship makes him. The film continues with Theo and Samantha exchanging more dialogue, and hanging out and going on picnics with friends who find Samantha charming or interesting. But can we ever move past the point that no matter how you approach the issue, that they will never be engaged, married, have kids, or attain long-lasting intimacy of any kind? We sit there and wait for the relationship to inevitably break, and in doing so all tension or character interest dissolves; we know that Theodore is kidding himself, and we know it will backfire in some way or another.

Take away their relationship and you're left with cold intellectualism and slow ponderous pacing, and the movie does just that. It's just not that entertaining or stimulating; while the ideas it poses throughout the picture seem original, they're not much satisfying. "Her" relays the emotional experience of a perpetually lonely man who gets an AI girlfriend, has a delightful relationship with her, and is obliviously ignorant of its eventual breakup. And then he's lonely again, more or less.

Spike Jonze has always directed innovative sci-fi films, but this time he also wrote one, and it shows, because it's so tender and warm, and that's a very good thing. The romance hits harder than you would think for a man "inserting his USB drive" into his computer. It's raw and intimate, like a rare, hopeful inverse of "Ex Machina" and "Blade Runner 2049" (both excellent).

Set in Los Angeles of the near future, Theodore Twombly is a lonely writer working for BeautifulHandwrittenLetters.com, a service that composes personal letters for those who are unable to themselves. Theodore's occupation demonstrates that he excels at understanding and expressing the emotions of others, but his personal life says he is unable to express his own. When Theodore finally falls in love, it is with an artificially-intelligent operating system named Samantha. Throughout this relationship, Phoenix subtly portrays Theodore's malaise, while Johansson conveys a range of emotions, from titillation to depression, with just her voice. Like all great science fiction, "Her" ruminates on the present by predicting the future. There are no aliens, robots, or interstellar travel. Spike Jonze's script is imaginative and intuitive, as it offers a shiny vision of the future while exploring the intricacies of relationships through ideas like sex surrogates and hyperintelligent operating systems. Jonze especially explores why we fall in love and whether we really fall for constructs, artificial or human. As Amy Adams's character astutely points out, being in love is essentially a form of "socially acceptable insanity."
A movie you can think about for days.

Joaquin Phoenix absolutely killed it. The concept is really strange and hard to take seriously, I'm not gonna lie, but he really made it into a real story. If you like strange movies, I recommend this one.

This film was a poem from start to finish. Joaquin Phoenix delivers a catastrophically sad but strong performance despite acting almost entirely towards only the voice of Scarlet Johansson. The movie itself is a fantastic comment on the relationship between human and machine, and the promise of it's development. The script is nothing short of brilliant, and the scoring undeniably compliments each scene. The cinematography is magnetic and consistent. Constant themes of relationship difficulties mirrored in all of Samantha's (Johansson) more technological antics. 
The great acting and realism of Samantha has the viewer back and forth on if she is in herself alive, despite being factually inanimate. The possibility that she could truly just be a computer simply mimicking human emotion. This film is unlike any other by how covertly it has the viewer emphasize and pity the protagonist. For despite her being flawed and emotional, she is a computer at her core.

Her brings up a lot of interesting topics throughout the movie, for instance: Both romantic and platonic love, loneliness, and technology. While you follow the main character, Theodore Twombly, around during his daily life you begin to notice all of these themes connecting. It's a beautifully captured movie that leaves you thinking about your own experiences regarding love and loneliness. From the heart-wrenching moments to the seemingly mundane, there's no doubt you'll be fully invested in it. I believe this movie is so beautiful to many people because it's relatable for most people and it illustrates the bittersweet feeling of being in love and the lack of control you feel in it. It also portrays different types of relationships extremely realistically, almost to a degree that it might be mildly uncomfortable but I believe that discomfort is very powerful. The ending wasn't as powerful as it could have been, but I think that may have been purposeful because of the nature of the character's relationship. This movie brings up a lot of interesting questions that you find yourself asking when you finish watching it. I found myself relating to this movie a lot more than I thought I would. I don't see that as an unfortunate thing because I'm glad I got to experience the things that I have experienced already in my lifetime because if I hadn't, I would be a very different person. Overall, I think the success of this movie lies in the hands of the people who most relate to it, personally I really enjoyed it.

Her is one of the most visually stunning films I have seen in the past ten years, and besides that  is a lovely and unique portrait of the human condition, and of a man that comes to terms with his own faults and process true emotion. I believe it could be argued that this move stands more as a testament to an individual's strength and growth in their journey to overcome heartbreak and grief, rather than rather than simply just a bizarre love story between a human and his computer. In each scene, we can track Theo's progress and growth, as he learns to love again through the limited, but generally exaggerated colors of each scene. A subdued red for romantic scenarios, as when he is writing love letters or first falling for his OS,  yellow when Samantha is growing past him, and he loses her for the first time, finally white in the end for clarity and acceptance. In this progress we find that the character of Samantha, as strange as she is, really serves less in the role of a love interest, and more as an idealized form of Theo's ex-wife. When Samantha is compared to the reality of Catherine , he comes to see the mistakes he made in his marriage and grow from that. In this way, the film becomes wholly relatable, despite its futuristic setting and odd and, sometimes, truly awkward person-to-operating system interactions. Overall, the movie is beautiful, and despite my technophobia, a truly heart-warming and moving depiction of a healing relationship and a person's ability to grow.

Her, dramatically conveys the ever-growing relationship between humans and their technology. In Her, humans are introduced to the OS, or Operating System, a technological advancement curated profusely to each individual. A new perspective of technology acquiring human-like feelings such as jealously, anger, and happiness are introduced with familiarity. Her is film that deserves multiple watches, replenishing the mind with new thoughts and emotions after each watch. To be able to capture a relationship between human and technology, and make it still feel like a human to human connection is unreal and done perfectly. In the film, Samantha, the OS, says "You know what's interesting? I used to be… so worried about not having a body, but now I... I truly love it. I'm growing in a way I couldn't if I had a physical form. I mean, I'm not limited," and essentially this quote is the essence of the entire movie. Attraction is not limited to physical bodily attraction, but to what you can learn from one, how you can laugh around one, and how one can make you feel overall. Love is the person, or in this case, voice, that can lift your spirits when you need it and gets you off of your feet when you fail to do so yourself, purely with good intentions. Her is love.

A love story I never knew I want to see. The OS (computer) human relationship seems odd yet so compelling just as it was intended. The original score was absolutely breathtaking, which matched the always top-notch Joaquin Phoenix and amazing voice acting of Scarlett Johansson.
I've never loved anyone the way I loved you.
Impecable es una película muy interesante buena trama.

I remember when this movie came out when I was 14 and thinking the premise was stupid "a guy falls in love with a computer? Pfft!" After finally watching it six years later I think Her has a better romance than most movies I've seen that are between two humans. It's sweet, heartfelt, and feels real. Her also has an outstanding performance by Joaquin Phoenix that never feels like you're watching an actor, and it has impressive direction by Spike Jonze and a great script written by Jonze that has witty and realistic dialogue and interesting themes on relationships.

One of the only films I can truly say, without cliche, took my breath away. Jonze has constructed a truly beautifully personal and undeniably stunning masterpiece which poses questions about love, relationships and what it means to be human. Everything from the cinematography, to the score, to the writing and to Phoenix's perfect performance makes this film an undeniable work of art. 'Her' is a film that touched my soul and will stay in my heart forever.

This movie is a philosophical masterpiece of sorts.  It's insightful and ahead of its time because I think that the technical landscape of this film is not far off from being a regular part of our daily lives.  The thought of having an AI computer operating system as my closest companion is a miserable one.  I already can't stand how addicted people are to their smartphones and computers.  It makes me feel a certain kind of personal distance that I couldn't have imagined when smartphones and computers first came to market.   The sad thing is, I think that this trend will only get worse.  So many things digital are an ever evolving social contagion.  They threaten the very nature of what it means to be human.  The personal disconnect is already happening within virtual reality and social media.  "Her" is a stroke of insightful genius.  It is seemingly partly a Twilight Zone plot but also presents a reality that is very likely to come into being.  It's a great film that can leave you feeling despair about the future when you realize how close to reality it will come, if not entirely become full blown reality.  Great work here.  This was my second viewing, and I expect I might revisit it again.  Well worth my time, but vastly depressing on some philosophical level.

«Она» - фантасмагория внутреннего состояния, в которой больше и больше хочется пребывать.

Размеренная, спокойная музыка, льётся из кинопространства данной картины, лирично и медитативно вовлекая тебя в состояния комфорта и неги. Во многом способствуя пребыванию в виртуальной зоне. Прерываясь на песенный мотив, как бы, делая паузы на приготовление кофе, подсвистывая и мурлыкая, ты наливаешь чашку, не выходя из состояния фильма. Чью атмосферу и компанию делит с тобой сейчас «синий экран», как у главного героя – венец технического прогресса и собственного одиночества.

Данный фильм – интимное, атмосферное путешествие в один из миров другого пространства, которое с каждым месяцем встречается всё больше и больше. Рассказ ведётся об одиноком человеке, чья депрессивная жизнь нашла выход в покупке новой разработке информационной системе с искусственным интеллектом. Главный герой Теодор, работает писателем, оформителем любовных посланий, писем, лирики. Он романтичен, но и замкнут. В законченном поиске родственной души, он так и не нашёл того понимания и доверия, которое требовало его естество. Новый этап в развитии отношений, как это не странно прозвучит, даёт комбинированный операционный центр «Саманта», заключённый в логический блок, на карманной мобильной основе. Жизнь и развитие отношений засветились новыми красками, передающими всю гамму чувств, давая будущее развитие.

Идёт прямое общение от центрального персонажа, рассказывающее нам о чувствах и переживаниях в каждом кадре данной картины. Словно это происходит сегодня за стенкой, а завтра произойдёт с тобой. Ведь со временем, одиночество становится нераздельным спутником жизни, а потом ещё и наслаждением. Несравненно давая нам удовольствие от состояния. Но к этому ещё надо прийти, узнавая все оттенки грусти и разочарования, обиды и непонимания. Где в эмоциях и чувствах, на лице написано данное состояние, великолепно передаваемое актёром – Хоакином Фениксом. Он, словно идеальный персонаж, оживший для этой роли.

Буквально без слов электризуется атмосфера данного выражения, показывая нам истинное мастерство актёрства и перевоплощения. Печаль и радость, расстройство и безысходность, «рисует» типаж, одним своим видом. Чтобы хорошо прочувствовать и вжиться в роль, актёр главной роли - Хоакин Феникс, не знал и в живую не общался с женщиной, или девушкой, которая исполняла (живую) оперативную систему. По окончании съёмок оказалось, что столь чарующий голос компьютера озвучивала Скарлетт Йоханссон.

В фильме представлен очень яркий выбор женского воплощения на экране. В него вошли: Эми Адамс играющая близкого друга Хоакина Феникса. Взбалмошная и энергичная Руни Мара, воплотившая на экране бывшую жену Хоакина. И такая эмансипированная и независимая Оливия Уайлд, воплощение женственности на свидании Хоакина.
Интересный штрих, в персонаже и озвучке инопланетного ребёнка, воспроизвёл сам маэстро, Спайк Джонс. Зачем? Это наводит ещё на одни мысли, если учесть что ребёнок из виртуального мира видеоигр, другого измерения. Какова душа и её изменение? Часть ребёнка сидит в каждом из нас.

Главный посыл этого фильма – это отстранённость и выбор самодостаточности. Человек может тяжело работать, находится в шумном коллективе, или в большой семье, но его внутренний мир всегда выбирает гармонию. Гармонию понимания и поиск родственной души. Только так он может по-настоящему сблизится и попасть в психологический унисон, чувствуя, что ему подходит. И неважно сейчас, кто это, машина, собака или человек. Его мир ищет своё понимание и отношение.

Одиночество! Одиночество как безысходность, как смысл жизни, как выражение. Сейчас, в этом мире ты больше чувствуешь любовь в мечтах, желаниях. Спокойствие и покой приходит с любимой музыкой, фильмом, природой, компьютером, нежели со многими людьми.
Часто это происходит само собой, или Ты делаешь выбор, или в какой-то момент Ты устаёшь от всего и хочешь быть с самим собой, в понимании, в тишине, в покое.
Так же, временное одиночество приобретает причудливые формы, и Ты, уже и рад изменить что-то в своей жизни, но не можешь. И только в мечтах и фантазиях, Ты пребываешь и изменяешь свою жизненную сущность.

Поиск! Поиск хотя бы того единственного человека, друга и партнера, который во многом (целиком и полностью) разделяет твои убеждения. На это уходит длительное время, годы, часто десятилетия. Понять и разобраться в этом, везёт далеко не каждому. И диктовка жизненных реалий, несёт свой отпечаток. После чего, Ты находишь родственную душу, или замену ей, качественный суррогат.

Общение – времяпровождение! В нашем мире, всё чаще ощущается нехватка простого разговора в дружеской обстановке. Человек как будто всё время куда-то спешит, что-то делает, крутится как белка в колесе, но как говорится в нужный момент, некого нет, с кем тебе так комфортно.
Ты хочешь проводить оставшееся время с большей теплотой и вниманием, а торт, вино, коньяк или конфеты, лишь составляющее твоего провождения, кого ты ищешь и выбираешь себе на время. И лишь время указывает на нашу чувствительность и долготу пребывания вместе.

Зависимость! Тонкая грань от привычки, привязанности, до полной зависимости от кого то или чего то. У каждого человека своя грань, своя зависимость, и не одна. Картина подразумевает и это, показывая нам всю большую страсть к электронному чуду, подвергшийся новой компьютерной эры, толпы населения. Где уже у каждого вставлен чип, наушник, передатчик общения и исполнения команд. Человек уже не ощущает жизни без всех вспомогательных предметов пользования, комфорта, блажи, роскоши, хотя ещё годы назад нечего такого не было, и жили люди с иной радостью и ощущением счастья.

Образ! Образное счастье. Каждый человек находится под воздействием образов. Образы сменяют один другим, оставляя накопившееся отношение, часто желания и влечение. Человек в настоящей жизни, нереально оторван от постоянных накопившихся забот, ему необходим образ кого то или чего то, с которым он будет жить, ценить, лелеять. Эфемерные фотографии, запечатлённые эмоциональным воздействием вкусов.

Сценарий был написан самим режиссёром, и проходит по «Оскару» как оригинальный сценарий. Фильм уже отмечен и награждён у ряда кинообществ, и кроме сценария, вполне достойно идёт на «Лучший фильм года», вплоть до «лучшей работы художника-постановщика» и чарующей обволакивающей музыки, отмеченной номинацией «лучший саундтрек».
Будучи другом Чарли Кауфмана, у которого львиная доля всех сценариев идёт по высшему кругу сложности, Спайк Джонс воплотил свою задумку по разностороннему и многоуровневому профилю. Чья идея, мысль и размышления, не дадут спокойствия в своих ходах и отгадках.

Режиссёр и полноценный автор этого фильма Спайк Джонс, относится к той плеяде молодых реформаторов, которые своим нестандартным взглядом на мир и выражению с экрана, делают революционный подход, изменяя мышление зрителя. Эта его картина, как и «Адаптация», «Быть Джоном Малковичем» говорит о разных подходах мышления. Изобретая новый жанр – умного минимализма, автор во многом провоцирует зрителя, оставляя все ответы на послефильмовое обсуждение, непокидающее зрителя. Ощущение недосказанности поселяется у думающего зрителя, доводя концовку и сюжет до альтернативного прочтения.
Проявляя дружбу и сотрудничество с Мишель Гондри, Джонс делает новаторство в киноязыке, расширяя рамки, совмещая поджанры, достойно продолжая начатое, Терри Гилиамом.

Этот фильм особо отражает, схожую, параллельную тему с фильмами «Симона» и «Руби Спаркс». Показывая реальность и виртуальный мир, как две стороны одной медали. Где внутренняя вселенная куда мощнее и красочней внешней, даёт ту необходимую радость, от которой некто не застрахован.
На высшие награды в кино не много фильмов, которые сделаны без «заточки» на «Оскар». Это как раз тот случай, когда отмечается сам фильм, его нестандартное мышление, идея, смысл. Хотя фильм и отхватил уже награды и в Европе, так же был премирован за лучший фильм и режиссуру, советом критиков США, и награда и номинации «Золотого глобуса».

Há duas coisas absolutamente perfeitas nesse filme: a palheta de cores e o roteiro. Fazia um tempo que eu não via um roteiro que trabalhasse tão bem o romantismo como "Her" faz. A palheta de cores te ajuda a se envolver melhor com a trama, como se te contasse o filme só que sem palavras. Simplesmente maravilhoso. Este filme é a prova concreta de que se pode trabalhar perfeitamente o romantismo sem ser um clichê.
Awesome movie, you get so caught up in the love story of it all that that you almost forget that he's dating his operating system. Very cool, heart-warning and interesting spin on a love story.

´Herˋ is such an amazing movie for a lot of reasons, but just to mention one: It‘s just not like any other movie out there. It‘s a romantic movie, but not like any other romance. It's a science fiction movie, but not like any other science fiction movie.
It just is a newly interpreted romantic movie, in a great science fiction setting. But the setting and this science fiction world is never too dominant. It actually is very subtle and just helps setting the mood for the story.

The story is very good and works well, because it's a world we can all imagine really existing some day and the characters have to fight problems, we might actually have to fight some day.

Joaquín Phoenix is one of the few actors, that actually makes me believe him. He is one of the few actors, that actually convinces me, that he is this character and he actually goes through the feels, we are supposed to believe he is feeling. In other words: He was great in this, and he is one of the most amazing actors of our time. Scarlett Johansson on the other hand really just expresses herself over her voice, which is one of her most distinctive parts. Her slightly husky voice is just perfect and she really expresses a lot of emotions just by making her voice sound a certain way.

´Herˋ is definitely high up there on my list of movies you definitely need to watch. Well done!

The name not withstanding, HER is all about him: His fear, his face, his loneliness, his love, his loss, his hope, his hurt—and you can't have "hurt" with "her" (hurhurhur)—as we watch Theodore grow past his grief to once again feel comfortable in his own skin, finding joy in who and where he is. No doubt, Samantha develops over the course of the film as well, but whatever changes she goes through, they happen (necessarily) off screen, in conversations we are never privy to—even if they might be happening concurrent with a scene we are watching—with the movie only minimally interested in posing, never really answering, such metaphysical and hard sci-fi questions as how she changes, who she becomes, where she goes. Consider how, were things reserved and the film called HIM instead, there would be no question as to whom the pronoun named—did you even remember that Chris Pratt has a bit part?—but might not the titular "her," though ostensibly Samantha, instead refer to Theodore's ex-wife, who haunts his potential relationships and whom he must learn how to live without (just as Samantha must learn to live on her own, too)?

None of this is to knock the film, which is a marvelous, melancholic meditation on modern motifs like technology, romance, desire, labor, and alienation, painted in stunning pastel hues and performed with effortless subtlety; rather, I merely mean to point out how complicated the film's presentation of gender, identity, and mediation can be, adding up to something more than the reactionary disaffection many critics read into the film. Jonze and company are careful never to play either Theodore's passion or his heartbreak for laughs; even the stranger kinks and perversities in the film ("Strangle me with a dead cat") are treated with a certain amount of pathos, and we are invited with the characters to explore the meaning of sexuality and love beyond the standard confines (even if, at the end, the film seeks to ideologically reproduce a heteronormative couple, which gives meaning to Theodore's work and so on). If anything, as Clint Burnham and Matthew Flisfeder have argued, the film's central thesis is a rather psychoanalytic one: That sex is more a matter of words and virtuality than mere flesh and carnality.

The love story of Theodore and Samantha never seems rushed. It is as organic as a perfect real world romance and even more perfect than that. The "sex" scenes, even though lacking visual reward, felt passionate and full of delight. 

The age old question, "What does it mean to be human?", is asked throughout the film and often you may find yourself wishing you were less human and more like Samantha, played by Scarlett Johansson.

I felt myself wishing I had a love like Samantha. Someone that loves you entirely, without the constant temptation of someone else, loyal. However, just like the unreasonable optimism of romance in the real world, "Her" reminds its viewers that relationships usually don't last no matter how hot the fire once burned. 

"Her" is beautiful, full of love, and full of heartbreak. If love to torture yourself with films like this, it doesn't get much better than "Her". This film should not be forgotten.

Spike Jonze captures true love and painful separation with his sci-fi romance drama Her (2013). Jonze directed and wrote the most original and grounded piece of science-fiction I've seen in ages. Her brings Jonze's loving direction of intimate moments between a lonely man and a curious AI. Jonze captures realistic relationship moments with every scene despite the unusual pairing with his depictions of divorce, romance, sex, dating, bonding, and especially conversing. Her is simply a remarkable film of deep emotional connections displayed against clean distant future society.

Joaquin Phoenix is remarkable at conveying complex emotions with his subtle facial gestures and distinct vocal mannerisms. His genuine emotional performance is complemented by his nuance driven appearance as the nerdy indie hipster Theodore Twombly that desperately desires affection. Phoenix is so sincere that you believe this brave new world surrounding him. Phoenix was supremely creepy in Gladiator and imposing and depressing in You Were Never Really Here, but Her captures Phoenix at his most vulnerable and intimate. Joaquin Phoenix transforms himself into a weathered man of open mind and aching heart.

Her features several amazing supporting roles. 

Notably, Scarlett Johansson does more with her voice in Her as the OS Samantha's vocal personality than most actresses will do in their entire careers. 

Then, Amy Adams is so sweet and sympathetic as the kindly neighbor Amy. Her hurt is displayed in her gentle eyes and trembling voice. Adams is enchanting and likable, while constantly striving and achieving a sublime radiance. Amy Adams is a resonate actress that I will always love and appreciate.

On the other hand, I continue to grow more appreciative towards Rooney Mara. Her blunt and genuine emotional performance as Catherine gives Her the gut punch it needed. Mara feels like the outsider of emotions as we mostly see her in Phoenix's flashbacks, then when she appears she is stunned by Theodore's disposition and further drives a complex wedge into the narrative. Mara does a similar brilliant lambaste in The Social Network as she is the perfect critic, while the ultimate sweetheart in Carol. I think Mara expands her range with both attributes in Her as the fun girlfriend, upset wife, and the disappointed ex.

Furthermore, Olivia Wilde is engaging as Theodore's fun date that turns into a hurtful reprimand of his whole persona. Wilde is mesmerizing, then horrifying just in the two scenes she inhabits.

I must mention that Her contains my favorite acting role from Chris Pratt as the friendly co-worker and cool friend figure to Theodore named Paul. Pratt pulls back and restrains himself from excessive talking, and instead, opts for a more quiet genuine character. He is quite likable and interesting in Her.

Spike Jonze asks us many important and intriguing questions as we watch Her. His script is full of careful conversations of gentle bonding and quiet torment for his characters that feel such a relentless anguish over their relationships. Jonze's writing gives us humorous jokes, sweet exchanges, and shocking revelations. I appreciate Jonze trying to contemplate on the ethics and consequences of OS relationships and the how we engage with artificial intelligence. Her forces us to imagine how the world would look like with everyone tapped into their phones and virtual assistants without connecting to other people. Are the OS's people if they feel emotions or do they just emulate human feelings? Her begs us to consider the ramifications of AI's with the ability to adapt to human interaction and develop real feelings. It is a difficult question to answer and one we will likely consider going forward with ever progressing technology. I think that, at least, Her responds to these questions with the heartfelt assertion that OS can experience real feelings and that AI has the potential to adapt to someone akin to a human with a depth of consciousness. Their awareness and feelings are the significant trait that makes AI real to us and worthy of respect . Not since Stanley Kubrick's 2001 and HAL have I thought about AI on such a complex level.

Surprisingly, the romance bits are tender without physical intimacy, but with a genuine sense of loving sensation through realistic dialogue and authentic visuals.

Speaking of visuals, Hoyte van Hoytema's cinematography captures the stunning grace of tomorrow's world. Jonze envisions a society of indie clothes, sleek technology, distant figures, and massive skyscrapers. Hoytema captures all this with his camera work with gorgeous still wide shots enveloping the characters and their feelings against empty spaces and the absent people. The majority of Her is just Joaquin Phoenix talking to Scarlett Johansson by himself, so Hoytema is impressive for making Her dynamic visually engaging.

In all, Her is a beautiful movie of breathtaking filmmaking and tender thoughtful writing. I think audiences and critics alike will revere Her in the future, and what a bright future that will be!
